addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

vij Octo
b
1590 M
r
Bodeley from the
Hagh
to my L./
For hir ma
ties
l
res
to other Townes
viz
Harlem
Tergonde
Gorchum
Roterodam
Tergoes
Hir Ma
ties
l
res
to
e Towne of
Utrecht
in favour of
Paul Buis
./

page.lettertext:
fol.121r
May it please yo
r
L. to be advertised, that
after I had sent my last to yo
r
L. the last
of Sep
t
the very same day I receaved yo
rs
of
e 15 w
t
her Ma
ties
letters to
e townes
.
15
7br
And because it was first the advise of M
r
Buis,
that her Hig
nes
should write to
e several townes,
I acquainted him presently w
t
e teno
r
of the
letters, and w
t
e nomber that were signed, re-
questing his direction about
e deliverie. In
his opinion they were written to very good pur-
pose, and will steede her Ma
tie
exceedingly, for
may respectes. Chiefly for
e terrifieng of those,
that are so opposit in all thinges to her Hig
nes
desires.
The only want that he doth finde, is that nothing
is written to
Harlem
1
, Tergowde
2
, Gorchum
3
, Rote-
4
rodam, Tergoes
5
, whiche are principall townes, and
These 5 l
res
ar very
nedefull
send their Deputies to
e meeting of
e states. There
are also others to be specially regarded, as
En-
6
chusen
,
Horne
7
, Camphere
8
. Albeit there are some
These 3 also ar
nedefull
of these more honestly affected then some others,
yet in his judgement, the best affected of them
all, are assoone to be dealt w
t
all, or happely
sooner then
e woorst. For he knoweth the nature
of this people to be so tender, that the townes
will esteeme it for a singular honor, to be requi-
red to doe any thing, by peculiar letters from
her Ma
tie
and repute it otherwise for a kinde of
contempt, the greater townes in special, if they
be not that way respected, aswell one as an
other. Againe if it come in deliberation, in
any publike assembly of
e
Generall states
, what
course is to be taken for her Ma
ties
satisfaction
fol.121v
it is the
most
forwardnes of
e most devoted,
that will drawe
e other places to
a
good reso-
lution. In consideration wherof, lest her
Hig
nes
should be frustrat of those good effectes,
that her letters may produce, he hath wished me
in any case, to endevo
r
by all meanes possible,
that her Hig
nes
may be intreated, to signe other
letters to
e forsaid townes, and to delay the de-
liverie of these in my handes, till
e rest be re-
ceaved. Upon so good demonstration
of reason, as to my understanding, was made
unto me, I have presumed to folowe his ad-
vise, and to beseeche
yo
r
L. to intreat her
Hig
nes
for
e signing
of letters to those other townes
e necessite of these
8 l
res
to
e end I may adresse them to their places
all together: as in
e meane season, I doe not
misdoubt, but by yo
r
L. meanes, this litle stay
that I make, till I shall be advertised of her
Ma
ties
pleasure, will be construed to
e best.
I have certified yo
r
L. in a
former letter, of
e death of
Floris Tin
Advocat
of
Utrecht
. Among those that are proposed in
Floris t
y
deade
their newe election,
M
r
Buis
is chiefly named.
paule buiss mete to
supply
e place
Howbeit by
e secret practise of
e
Advocat of
Barnevelt
Holland
, and some others besides, not like to be
elected. To exclude him
e sooner, they give
it out against him, for a principal cause, That
her Ma
tie
doth not favor him. He doth not seeme
in any sort, to affect that office, having meanes
of his owne, to maintene an honest part. Never-
theles to notifie to
e world the lewdnes of
those, by whome he is abused, he hath moved
me earnestly, to become an humble suto
r
,
at her
fol.122r
Ma
tie
would vouchesafe, to write a letter in his favo
r
,
to
e states and towne of Utrecht,
to
e same effect,
a l
re
to utrecht
as he procured it once before: requiring
e repara-
tion of his credit among them, and restitution
of certaine gooddes,
at they doe wrongfully withold.
To make it somwhat cleerer, I have sett downe
e
substance,
at
e letter should contene, and I send
it heere a part, to be framed in suche sort, as her
Ma
tie
shall give order. He thinkes by this meanes
not only to attene to his right and credit, but to
e
publike conviction of those
at would have him in
her Hig
nes
disgrace. I have had some
experience in this place, of his unfained endevo
rs
,
to advance to
e uttermost her Ma
ties
service,
as
whiche in part heretofore I have signified to yo
r
L.
as I knowe
M
r
Wilkes
will doe it more effectually:
and still I finde him to continew in his wonted
disposition, delivering his minde in all his conver-
sation very honorablely and freely of her Ma
ties
procee-
dinges, w
t
out any feare of other mens displeasure:
so as for mine owne part, I see no man of this na-
tion, w
t
out exception of any, to shewe a better proofe
of his honest affection. In w
ch
respect I do
not doubt but yo
r
L. will be moved, to recom-
mend his request, to
e effecting of it: to
e end
he may perceave, that nether we that are heere,
have concealed his desertes, nor her Ma
tie
not esteemed
them. The fort of
Terheide
by
Breda
after it had abidden 400 shotte of
e Canon, fell
Terhed r
e
dred
to composition, to depart w
t
out Ensignes, armes or
baggage. By meanes wherof three principal townes,
Bommel
,
Breda
,
Hoesden
are greatly relieved, and
and the contrey freed from
e Enemies oppression.
fol.122v
It was thought very requisit, that
e forsaid fort,
should be rased: whiche was presently perfourmed,
and
e Count, as we thinke, is nowe before steen-
berghen, from whens we looke every houre to receave
good tidinges.
And so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Oc
t
7 1590
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
Because I am not sure,
that
e copie of
e letter
to
e townes is reserved,
I thought it convenient
to send it here inclosed.
